sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & 1\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$$

where the matrix A is:

$$\begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i\end{bmatrix}$$

In our case, the matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & 1\end{bmatrix}$$

So, we have:

$$a = 2, b = 1, c = -3, d = -1, e = 4, f = 2, g = 0, h = 5, i = 1$$

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

$$\det(A) = 2(4\cdot1 - 2\cdot5) - 1(-1\cdot1 - 2\cdot0) + (-3)(-1\cdot5 - 4\cdot0)$$

$$\det(A) = 2(4 - 10) - 1(1) - 3(5)$$

$$\det(A) = 2(-6) - 1 - 15$$

$$\det(A) = -12 - 1 - 15$$

$$\det(A) = -28$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix is -28.
